Thank you @cryptowanderer, @Vivek Singh, @Sachin Mittal and @Angela Gilhotra for the unique experience! :kernel-love:
Please continue spreading the love, bringing more suns onboard and polishing those mirrors. :grin:
Thank you, wonderful and unique individuals who I had (or hadn’t) a pleasure to meet here! :hearts: May you all succeed in every adventure! :rainbow:

Truly grateful to have been part of this journey. The past 8 weeks have been quite memorable for me. The conversations, the lessons, the people, everything that makes KERNEL "KERNEL" came together and made it wonderful. Not enough can be said to thank all the Stewards who paved this entire block @Vivek Singh @Angela Gilhotra @Sachin Mittal @cryptowanderer @johnx25bd and everyone else involved! This experience was a gift, and I am glad I was one of the few lucky ones to be able to receive it so far.

Thanks to all the mentors and guests who took time off their hectic days to talk to us Fellows, and guide us through our journey. The juntos, fireside, KERNEL Cafe, One-to-one Offerings, etc. was just beautiful. I am glad I was able to speak with many of you in <!subteam^S0224NELPGD|@kb3> and I hope we keep the ties strong. I love how everyone in this group is either building something or looking for inspiration to start. I love what everyone is working on, and I wish everyone the best in their journeys from here on.

Lots of gratitude and love to you all!
Special shoutouts to @Paulo Almeida @Serg Lotz @Rahul // r-nk.xyz @Leo Lara @Rev Miller @En Canada @Tagan Horton @stickykeys @Sebastian T F @Aiswarya Walter @alisha and everyone else whom I've met in KERNEL, and had conversations with.



:v::kernel-love::musical_note:  to all!

“Know that thankfulness is from the highest of stations, and it is higher than patience and fear and detachment of this world.”  - Imam Al-Ghazali

Cultivating gratitude is the most beautiful art we can create. The social, emotional dynamics and constant personal growth that is required for the deep collaboration that forges hyper effective teams is grossly understated. For that reason I am grateful to my friend, peer, co-founder and comrade in Web 3 @Tagan Horton. Without her spirit, energy, fortitude and self determination the KERNEL experience and Dakar Gallery would not be possible. 

KERNEL has been a lesson in play and a journey of gratitude. While it is impossible to pinpoint one person or Kernel experience I am grateful to @Vivek Singh for setting the tone for gratitude per our first conversation days before KERNEL started. Furthermore I’m forever grateful for the insight and wisdom shared by @cryptowanderer that both challenged me yet made me feel at home in my personal study; and for @Sachin Mittal, @johnx25bd and the inspiration and feedback from @Jeet Raut, @Nuno Neto, @Abe Uccello, @tina, @Paul Gadi, @Paulo Almeida @Rahul // r-nk.xyz @Rajesh Kadam @Reuben Bramanathan @Rebecca Mqamelo. Just to name a few. To all those I Kernel that I have spoken with and listened to I am forever grateful. 

“May the gratitude in my heart Kiss all the Universe” - Hafiz

First I thought I will mention everyone in Kernel I crossed my path with - but realised the list will be way too long.

So thank you wonderful stuarts @Vivek Singh @cryptowanderer @Simona Pop @Sachin Mittal @Angela Gilhotra @johnx25bd for putting this program together and supporting us all along the way. It was so much more than just learning - it expanded my understanding of the world in general and web3 in particular, created a sense of belonging and gifted me new connections with so many wonderful inspiring people.

Thanks to Kernel mentors for taking their precious time to guide me in and out of office hours. My project wouldn't be the same without the Kernel input.

Thanks to all <!subteam^S0224NELPGD|@kb3> fellows for all shared experiences: fascinating firesides, thought provoking juntos, late night (thanks to my timezone) Kernel cafe hang outs and endless Zoom calls. You are the best community in web 3 one can find.

My heart is full of gratitude. Sending you all big hugs :hugging_face:

Truly grateful to @cryptowanderer for all the words and beyond:pray:, to @Dhruv Malik, Dollar Monopoly, @johnx25bd for believing that we are not crazy and the support :pray:, to @Muskan for ideas how to scale:pray:!
Thank you! :hearts:

immensely grateful to @cryptowanderer , @johnx25bd , @Abe Uccello , @Ellena Rapaport , @Yulia Babanova and others for the inclusive discussion on metaverses , *the concept of present*   ( and indeed i am putting that in bold coz its quite expansive for me  )  , the tech ecosystem , free speech  and the  religious scriptures  across the religions  to satisfy   the human inquisitiveness . kudos to all

Hey all, time flew, and now with things calming down a bit, I want to express my gratitude towards those that made the past few months so special, It was a big wave for me and ethblockart, and without the help of mentors, fellows, and the kernel team, I wouldn't have been able to stay atop the surfboard!

For starters, I wanna express my gratitude towards many of the mentors, present and supportive in genuinely important ways throughout this adventure: Defi_Dad, @Thomas Klocanas, @Linda Xie, @Shawn Cheng @Ben Lakoff, @Dave Rodman, @Harsh Rajat and @Scott Moore. You folks are amazing and your help instrumental.

Other fellows, always positive, helpful and inspiring in the best way possible even while busy with their own adventures, like @Simon Fremaux, @Carl Farterson and the best-practices gang, @Holly Grimm, and the DADA team, even if we didn't interact much directly, know you've been an inspiration for many years!

And how can we not be grateful for the Kernel team, receiving us all with open arms and unparalleled patience and kindness, @Sachin Mittal, @Vivek Singh and others, one-of-a-kind human beings which I'm honoured to have met and spend time with. :pray:

Lastly, I can't write this without a special note to @cryptowanderer, embracing the project mission from the start, contributing in ways I couldn't have expected, making what the project is today a reality, you're amazing, thank you again.

One can say riding a market like we're experiencing today as a solo builder with a somewhat market-fit product can feel like choosing Jaws, Maui as a go-to surf spot while still learning to surf, sure some can pull off the once-in-a-lifetime herculean task of achieving so alone...But what enables surfers to, time and time again, execute this impressive feat, a humbling celebration of our ability to face head-first the scariest challenges posed by nature, are exactly other humans, community, supporters often not celebrated, from the tow-in jet sky riders, the lifeguards bringing you oxygen, to the chanting crowd by the coast and even the sharks keeping you alert.

Back to the point, what is being done here at Kernel is unique, every step planned with a level of care hard to find elsewhere, and it is also upon us all to keep this flame awake and the kernel culture principled, I hope to in the future be able to help others the same way I was helped here, for that is what makes the world go round.

For now, thank you Kernel, for all, and happy spring! :seedling:

Here are left over thoughts & some notes from our last Junto that may lend to David’s thoughts on indigenous influence in our urgent times. His great articulation of the benefits of consensus & the creation of new bottom up structures-- seems to speak to where the weight of transformative power of indigenous dialogue resides. Not having to start from scratch in autonomous creation of new sustainable structures is a huge advantage we shouldn’t take for granted on any front.

Insights to western misnomers of indigenous social structures through a matrilineal indigenous & _Kanienke'ha'ka perspective (misnomer - Mohawk)_: 

Female/Male Chief = “The Best of us”-- chosen by women title-holders with 100% consensus decision making. “(De)horned” by women when deemed ineligible for title. No campaigns or elections, to avoid any “perception of corruption.” Perceptions of possible pillow talk amongst representatives means title-holders can not be married to each other for example.

Hereditary - Is reference to clan —not blood, or immediate family. Used as mechanism to protect against nepotism or any “perceptions of corruption,” not to ensure nepotism as in the western context. Even if not blood & across the territory for example— inter clan marriage is illegal. Representatives can not hand down title to their children-- as in the western meaning of hereditary monarchies. Clan is blood only in the case that legally clan can only be given by mother to children. If your mother is does not have a clan but your father does you are his  “__” clan “hung about the neck.” This becomes relevant in case of legal title eligibility. 

Elected Tribal or Band councils across the hemisphere today do not abide by any of these native constitution laws —their chief title only being legal in context of municipalities of respective colonial nations — which means they have signed away their rightful nation to nation status of the Two Row Wampum Peace Treaty. We can never express our gratitude to the women of the Longhouse in Kahnawake, who have kept this Peace Treaty alive for us to leverage today. 

Slavery - The Longhouse is adamant about the absence of slavery in the hemisphere. The Longhouse is also always careful not to speak on the protocols of other native nations. So this strong stance on slavery is likely a reference to the continuity that also exist amongst those distinctions—from a common history & cosmology “the journey of the corn.”

This is consistent with the Longhouse’s oral documentation of “the bringing into the heart fire” concept of indigenous ”justice systems.” Hereditary in the indigenous context becomes important in Wengrow’s mention of “hereditary slavery”--because it likely points to an adoption into clan mechanism, merely getting lost in an ethnographic translation. To jail or imprison a human being in Longhouse oral documentation has always been illegal. So it follows that anything even closely resembling the chattel style slavery we attach to the word would inherently be deemed illegal as well. The worst of crimes meant being marked on the face as the worst of offenders, to be easily identified by surrounding nations -- then let free in to the wilderness. Or killed immediately for the heinous offense. 

Hinting at possible matrilineal continuity across oceans — this is also consistent with other matrilineal justice mechanisms of Africa. Mentioned by polymath, physicist, anthropologist, archaeologist, linguist, historian —Cheikh Anta Diop. Diop describes precolonial west African nations having intricate protocols for bringing local/regional rule benders into the family for a determined period of time —after which it was then illegal to ever disparage the person by even mentioning the crime or this time of the person’s life. 

This last nuance actually points to elaborate cultural protections against free labor —as does clan adoption via “bringing into the heart fire” in the native context. 

Chattel slavery is largely dependent on quite the contrary elaborate cultural mechanisms of dehumanization — rhetoric of infidels was just as pop culture as minstrel shows, toys, cartoons food labels & children restaurants called “Little Black Sambo” as recent as the 80s here in the states for example. These indigenous systems seem to be humanizing as much as possible with protections against dehumanization.

This makes lot more sense than this “heart fire” phrasing being a sick euphemism for what is the Islamic origin of chattel slavery ,in which we are the most familiar in the west. As Graeber mentions the folks in the 1500s having a hard time believing natives had even heard of Jesus let alone (or practice human sacrifice to demons) denounce him. This may be a continuation of this same phenomenon via the slavery misnomer that is rooted in old world religious, political & economic systems. Far removed from a precolonial native world. 

“The forgotten slave trade” of east Africa & what was then — extensions of these east African nations into the Middle East. Resulted in an ethnic cleansing not unlike what has happened in modern Palestine in our lifetime. It also lasted long enough to overlap with the west African slave trade. 
Not unlike our real time awareness of geopolitics today, important history of both eras of African slavery are largely lost to highly politicized & or religious narratives, somehow skipping over indigenous spiritual/cultural influence in the regions for millenia. Diop mentions interesting west African context often left out — the “bringing into the heart fire” style justice systems were still intact in these still precolonial black African nations — this was exploited by slave traders before raids became necessary because these nations rose to the defense of their people after discovering the crime. 

None of this takes away from Graeber’s overall point of empirical political data over millenia giving robust design to political systems of the hemisphere. The details here merely add to the importance of Graeber’s work & due diligence in this area of study — work virtually unprecedented in his peers past or present. These details are also likely derivatives of the formulaic aspect of indigenous modes of social organization — explaining the cultural continuity in respective hemispheres. All distinct cultures of course but also self similar like the coast lines themselves, through common cosmological significations expressing beautiful social resilience in diversity. 

Graeber is also spot on in another remarkable and extremely relevant way for those of us here in this cohort together. Wage slavery is another kind of slavery we are familiar with — and this is where there is some actual real independent cultural overlap! The pre-colonial Five Nations Longhouse Confederacy was on the brink of falling into perpetual cycles of wage based slavery similar but likely also distinct from modern industrialized systems. 

This is oral documentation of nations coming out of war and into peace 2.5k yrs ago. Wampum shells for the beads on strings of sinew that was used for trade; were becoming commodified. Not from old world systems of settler colonial extraction & military market creation of course; the shells were becoming commodified by default of nations at war. War meant it simply wasn’t safe to collect these shells from the lakes. War eventually created a corrupted mind that was content to have others work for them via control of these shells. This mind was successfully transformed with matrilineal council that protected long term, against male dominant commodification of all strains of life — this lasted up until colonization. 

The League of Peace formed 2.5k yrs ago out of this empirical data matched with even older formulaic design that goes back to Sky Woman herself. This is a beautiful precedent that is desperately needed in these times. And Graeber’s words truly become prophetic in this context. @cryptowanderer @Vivek Singh @Magenta Ceiba @Sparrow Read

Really dig this <http://revistas.ucm.es/index.php/TEKN/article/view/52267/49998|paper> that posits this:

> Recursion is a big part of recursivity but it is not the whole story. Recursion refers to a system in which  outputs  at one iteration become inputs to the   next. Feedback loops, such as a thermostat regulating temperature in an hour, would be one example. Recursion can also be visualized: self-similar repeating elements  that can be seen when holding a mirror up to another mirror, Russian nesting dolls, the chambers of a nautilus’ shell, and fractal designs like the Sierpinski triangle are all examples of recursion. Recursion is used in a more specific way in computer science, as when a function calls upon itself in order to solve a larger, more complex problem (Hofstadter 1999). 
> Recursion is a powerful concept that has a very specific definition in mathematics and computer science. I have chosen to coin the neologism “recursivity” for two reasons. First, I do not want to instigate debates about whether or not something is “truly” recursive in the mathematical   sense. 
> Recursion is a  conceptual  basis for recursivity in the same way that “equality” is a conceptual basis for democracy; one need not ask how mathematicians define equality to use it. I want to make a clear distinction between the mathematical source material I am drawing from, and the kind of social relations that recursivity promotes. Recursivity is a social condition, not the dutiful execution of a mathematical property. In the same way, a worker that has been scientifically and minutely exploited through computer-aided Taylorism embodies an idea of efficiency, but this is still a far cry from the abstraction of efficiency in physics which might require a frictionless environment, bodies with infinite hardness or other precise idealizations.

received.message: I thought I'd drop a line here as I'm just jumping back into Kernel after quite a time away.  My web3 journey didn't start with Kernel but it did start with Gitcoin back in early 2019 after I heard a podcast with @Kevin Owocki that was my first step down the rabbit hole.  After hacking away on bounties for more than year (quite a few for Gitcoin Core), I saw the first mentions of the Kernel program and applied.  After a fruitful interview with @Vivek Singh and @Sachin Mittal, I waited a few weeks and wondered if I'd ever hear back.  I feel like the poster child for imposter syndrome in the web3 world and I was more than surprised when I got the email inviting me to join the Kernel Genesis Block.  The rest, as they say, is history.  I'm thankful for having been included in this community of builders and thinkers and also for the whole Gitcoin community of growing open source .  I'm definitely not the deepest thinker here or the best coder (not by a country mile), but it was this community that really helped me find my footing to go from where I was (someone who felt purposeless and unfruitful in my then vocation) to where I am now (an active, engaged dev working on Ethereum infrastructure who wakes up every day excited to do what I've been called to do and to see the world get turned upside down by what we're building).  So thank you @Kevin Owocki for building Gitcoin, @Vivek Singh, @Sachin Mittal,  and@cryptowanderer for Kernel, and to others along the way who have given me opportunities to build cool stuff and to be a part of web3 like @Rob Secord and @Ben Lakoff from Charged Particles, @Mike Elias from Idea Market, various folks from the Status/Nimbus team, @Shresth Agrawal, @Jose Aguinaga...etc.

attributes.value: Shresth -- thank you for your contributions to libp2p and other countless parts of KERNEL. We are happy to have you in the family.

Amazing!! Thanks for the shoutout @Harold Davis

Thank you so much @Harold Davis... it is like you read my mind, or I somehow knew you had written this while I was sleeping, because I woke up this morning thinking about just these things.  How coercive our use of money is, and because of that mindset, our use of tokens in crypto.  Even our language often reflects this - posting a "bounty" for example.  I will re-read this this again while I have my first coffee, but I wanted to give you these first reactions. :heart:

cc @Adrian le Bas @Nir Kabessa - recommend a read here as you embark on a series of conversations about the (conversational) projects you are building

@Harold Davis we are indebted to you for your contributions here!


The spirit of dialogue is, in short, the ability to hold many points of view in suspension, along with a primary interest in the creation of a common meaning.

We must have dialogues, we must share our thoughts. We must be able to think together. If we can’t think together and talk together, then we can do nothing together. Culture implies shared meaning in which everybody participates.

It is this story that @Harold Davis that really stood out for me. I mean, everything did in one way or another, but this one particularly felt like there was so much more to unlock to really understand the lessons to be learned here.

`Minding the peace - The League of Peace formed 2,500 years ago as a response to the social climate in North America. The commodification of wampum shells at the time led to the outbreak of war. War meant it simply wasn't safe to collect these shells from the lakes. In the tradition, war is the result of - and perpetuates - a corrupted mind which is content to have others work for it via control and commodification. This mind was successfully transformed by the matrilineal council that protected long term peace, right up until total colonization.`

When we commodify things, could it be that this is always the inevitable result? The act of commodification attempts to assign a 'value' to something.  Which works for goods, so they can be exchanged.  But we don't stop there.  When we turn living things, and people, into commodities that can be exchanged (human 'resources' our companies call them) this seems to only ever result in the killing of the thing we have tried to put a 'value' on.

There are many thing in just this one story that feels to me like important wisdom lost or ignored in much of what we see happening now.

@Harold Davis thank you brother :pray: I am beyond grateful for this contribution. While I watch the documentary and get things ready to deploy to prod, please enjoy some <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v4xZUr0BEfE|serious humour> somewhat linked to this sharing :heart:

Would love to connect again in realtime. Also available this weekend, except 5-6pm Sunday and 2-3pm Saturday. @Harold Davis apologies for being slow to continue the connection with Myra, snowed under but will do that this weekend.
this will work fine, thank you :pray: @Harold Davis @Sparrow Read @Holly Grimm maybe we can use zoom as there are no more seats at that table....
@Harold Davis this may interest you? <https://dailyhive.com/vancouver/senakw-squamish-first-nation-vancouver-rental-housing-development>

Just wanted to say thank you @Harold Davis for the invite to yesterday's meeting.  What an amazing range of topics, knowledge, wisdom. :pray:  I felt incredibly honoured to be there listening. :heart:
Thank you very much @Harold Davis :pray:

Dear friends. I have taken some time to put this together, because I am not a neutral observer :sweat_smile:

@Harold Davis here is my perspective of the TRW Council you so kindly invited me to. It need not go anywhere other than here, depneding on what you think of it. Thank you again for what was a great privilege. I hope that telling my experience honestly will be seen as my means of trying to honour the gifts given that day: <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1rAkarVUHUlXFHhclcD1c_mStGkgYdQz7aFKd7OJcC3k/edit?usp=sharing>

@Harold Davis - I think you pulled out an important point.  I don't see greed as natural.  Humans are not outside of Nature.  Nature isn't greedy, is it?  Therefore, it is something we learn through culture / environment.  What is learned can be unlearned.  Given the right environment.  (Thinking now about those mice which were used to demonstrate addiction, when taken out of their cages and given an interesting environment and something to do, weaned themselves off of their addictions.)
Thank you so much @Harold Davis - it was wonderful to learn from you and Desire and I look forward to more generative dialogue :heart:
@Sebnem there is a whole lot of collective sense making opportunity with @Harold Davis and others over the course of these next weeks (and beyond, I think).
let's wait for @Vivek Singh and @Harold Davis responses.
Thanks to @Harold Davis and @Jeevan Pillay for the great chat that we had about grassroots/indigenous organizations.

Hey all, time flew, and now with things calming down a bit, I want to express my gratitude towards those that made the past few months so special, It was a big wave for me and ethblockart, and without the help of mentors, fellows, and the kernel team, I wouldn't have been able to stay atop the surfboard!

For starters, I wanna express my gratitude towards many of the mentors, present and supportive in genuinely important ways throughout this adventure: Defi_Dad, @Thomas Klocanas, @Linda Xie, @Shawn Cheng @Ben Lakoff, @Dave Rodman, @Harsh Rajat and @Scott Moore. You folks are amazing and your help instrumental.

Other fellows, always positive, helpful and inspiring in the best way possible even while busy with their own adventures, like @Simon Fremaux, @Carl Farterson and the best-practices gang, @Holly Grimm, and the DADA team, even if we didn't interact much directly, know you've been an inspiration for many years!

And how can we not be grateful for the Kernel team, receiving us all with open arms and unparalleled patience and kindness, @Sachin Mittal, @Vivek Singh and others, one-of-a-kind human beings which I'm honoured to have met and spend time with. :pray:

Lastly, I can't write this without a special note to @cryptowanderer, embracing the project mission from the start, contributing in ways I couldn't have expected, making what the project is today a reality, you're amazing, thank you again.

One can say riding a market like we're experiencing today as a solo builder with a somewhat market-fit product can feel like choosing Jaws, Maui as a go-to surf spot while still learning to surf, sure some can pull off the once-in-a-lifetime herculean task of achieving so alone...But what enables surfers to, time and time again, execute this impressive feat, a humbling celebration of our ability to face head-first the scariest challenges posed by nature, are exactly other humans, community, supporters often not celebrated, from the tow-in jet sky riders, the lifeguards bringing you oxygen, to the chanting crowd by the coast and even the sharks keeping you alert.

Back to the point, what is being done here at Kernel is unique, every step planned with a level of care hard to find elsewhere, and it is also upon us all to keep this flame awake and the kernel culture principled, I hope to in the future be able to help others the same way I was helped here, for that is what makes the world go round.

For now, thank you Kernel, for all, and happy spring! :seedling:

Thanks to the Kernel Team, Mentors and awesome fellows. All of you have helped us shape some of the major decisions about our project and the way to take it forward :rocket:. I'm extremely grateful for having the opportunity to have interacted with the most passionate, talented, generous and philanthropic community I've ever had the fortune of coming into contact with. The range of concepts, fierce intellect and enormous compassion that I've been exposed to will be unforgettable.

When I started, I was deeply apathetic about the future of the human experience. But I leave KERNEL with a deep sense of optimism, tremendous excitement, and hope for humanity. You are all inspiring people, and I'm indebted to everyone who held my hand into the Web3 rabbit hole.

The world now appears as beautiful to me as it once had when I was a little kid. And I really mean that. Maybe that's Beginner's Mind.

received.message: I thought I'd drop a line here as I'm just jumping back into Kernel after quite a time away.  My web3 journey didn't start with Kernel but it did start with Gitcoin back in early 2019 after I heard a podcast with @Kevin Owocki that was my first step down the rabbit hole.  After hacking away on bounties for more than year (quite a few for Gitcoin Core), I saw the first mentions of the Kernel program and applied.  After a fruitful interview with @Vivek Singh and @Sachin Mittal, I waited a few weeks and wondered if I'd ever hear back.  I feel like the poster child for imposter syndrome in the web3 world and I was more than surprised when I got the email inviting me to join the Kernel Genesis Block.  The rest, as they say, is history.  I'm thankful for having been included in this community of builders and thinkers and also for the whole Gitcoin community of growing open source .  I'm definitely not the deepest thinker here or the best coder (not by a country mile), but it was this community that really helped me find my footing to go from where I was (someone who felt purposeless and unfruitful in my then vocation) to where I am now (an active, engaged dev working on Ethereum infrastructure who wakes up every day excited to do what I've been called to do and to see the world get turned upside down by what we're building).  So thank you @Kevin Owocki for building Gitcoin, @Vivek Singh, @Sachin Mittal,  and@cryptowanderer for Kernel, and to others along the way who have given me opportunities to build cool stuff and to be a part of web3 like @Rob Secord and @Ben Lakoff from Charged Particles, @Mike Elias from Idea Market, various folks from the Status/Nimbus team, @Shresth Agrawal, @Jose Aguinaga...etc.

The spirit of dialogue is, in short, the ability to hold many points of view in suspension, along with a primary interest in the creation of a common meaning.

We must have dialogues, we must share our thoughts. We must be able to think together. If we can’t think together and talk together, then we can do nothing together. Culture implies shared meaning in which everybody participates.

it all starts with a :seedling:

thank you @Rev Miller @Ben Lakoff @Vivek Singh @Sachin Mittal @johnx25bd @cryptowanderer @Angela Gilhotra :kernel-love:

We had an absolutely fantastic "Climate Impact Group" kickoff chat on Monday! The intention was just get together, geek out on all things decarbonising web 3 & leveraging things like DeFi to accelerate the vision of a planet positive, carbon negative future for all including jamming on things like the devastation faced by our oceans in example.

If you missed it, don't worry, you can find the recording in <#C01UUEDM934|feed-session-recordings> but essentially we spent a lot of time on intros & getting to know each other better which was lovely, had some climate convo led by @Raphael Haupt & some others, deciding that essentially we would co-ord in <#C01KHR1M0LA|jam-climate> & find a time that suited all of us as best as possible to make the event a reoccurring thing.

Thanks to all the fantastic people & minds that attended @Abe Uccello @Ben Lakoff @Holly Grimm @Raphael Haupt @Kevin Davis @Laurens De Poorter @Robin Roy Thomas.  Sorry to the people I've missed, had some difficulty finding your Slack @. Please DM me so can add you to the thread if you see this! :slightly_smiling_face:

#CLIMATEGANG

Hey all, time flew, and now with things calming down a bit, I want to express my gratitude towards those that made the past few months so special, It was a big wave for me and ethblockart, and without the help of mentors, fellows, and the kernel team, I wouldn't have been able to stay atop the surfboard!

For starters, I wanna express my gratitude towards many of the mentors, present and supportive in genuinely important ways throughout this adventure: Defi_Dad, @Thomas Klocanas, @Linda Xie, @Shawn Cheng @Ben Lakoff, @Dave Rodman, @Harsh Rajat and @Scott Moore. You folks are amazing and your help instrumental.

Other fellows, always positive, helpful and inspiring in the best way possible even while busy with their own adventures, like @Simon Fremaux, @Carl Farterson and the best-practices gang, @Holly Grimm, and the DADA team, even if we didn't interact much directly, know you've been an inspiration for many years!

And how can we not be grateful for the Kernel team, receiving us all with open arms and unparalleled patience and kindness, @Sachin Mittal, @Vivek Singh and others, one-of-a-kind human beings which I'm honoured to have met and spend time with. :pray:

Lastly, I can't write this without a special note to @cryptowanderer, embracing the project mission from the start, contributing in ways I couldn't have expected, making what the project is today a reality, you're amazing, thank you again.

One can say riding a market like we're experiencing today as a solo builder with a somewhat market-fit product can feel like choosing Jaws, Maui as a go-to surf spot while still learning to surf, sure some can pull off the once-in-a-lifetime herculean task of achieving so alone...But what enables surfers to, time and time again, execute this impressive feat, a humbling celebration of our ability to face head-first the scariest challenges posed by nature, are exactly other humans, community, supporters often not celebrated, from the tow-in jet sky riders, the lifeguards bringing you oxygen, to the chanting crowd by the coast and even the sharks keeping you alert.

Back to the point, what is being done here at Kernel is unique, every step planned with a level of care hard to find elsewhere, and it is also upon us all to keep this flame awake and the kernel culture principled, I hope to in the future be able to help others the same way I was helped here, for that is what makes the world go round.

For now, thank you Kernel, for all, and happy spring! :seedling:

I am so thankful!

“Know that thankfulness is from the highest of stations, and it is higher than patience and fear and detachment of this world.”  - Imam Al-Ghazali

Cultivating gratitude is the most beautiful art we can create. The social, emotional dynamics and constant personal growth that is required for the deep collaboration that forges hyper effective teams is grossly understated. For that reason I am grateful to my friend, peer, co-founder and comrade in Web 3 @Tagan Horton. Without her spirit, energy, fortitude and self determination the KERNEL experience and Dakar Gallery would not be possible. 

KERNEL has been a lesson in play and a journey of gratitude. While it is impossible to pinpoint one person or Kernel experience I am grateful to @Vivek Singh for setting the tone for gratitude per our first conversation days before KERNEL started. Furthermore I’m forever grateful for the insight and wisdom shared by @cryptowanderer that both challenged me yet made me feel at home in my personal study; and for @Sachin Mittal, @johnx25bd and the inspiration and feedback from @Jeet Raut, @Nuno Neto, @Abe Uccello, @tina, @Paul Gadi, @Paulo Almeida @Rahul // r-nk.xyz @Rajesh Kadam @Reuben Bramanathan @Rebecca Mqamelo. Just to name a few. To all those I Kernel that I have spoken with and listened to I am forever grateful. 

“May the gratitude in my heart Kiss all the Universe” - Hafiz
Thanks to @Paul Gadi for wise consul and direction
grateful to @Paul Gadi @Kyle Smith from KB3 and everyone else who joined <https://ethturin.eth.link> over the weekend! we made it.

Immensely grateful to @Jon Kol for challenging me to build something hard. @Jacob Franek - DeFi Alliance for helping me streamline my idea and focus on one problem at a time. @Theo RCX for giving me feedback on my idea and sharing his experience building Bunchy Protocol. @Paul Gadi My fellow Torontonian, for going through thought experiments with me on how my product deployment may play out and introuncing me to other projects to look into. @Mario Romero Zavala for an incredible discussion on defi, product development, using the scientific method and customer feedback when building products.
Super grateful for the insanely insightful convo about navigating gamification space with the wonderful @Paul Gadi this week :raised_hands::boom:

Thanks to all KERNEL fellows, friends, mentors and teammates for making this a memorable experience. It was a great summer jamming, laughing, learning and doing. Best of success to everyone on their projects and I look forward to staying connected here and beyond. As @Paul Gadi mentioned last night, this was truly the best reason to be sleep deprived. :joy::rolling_on_the_floor_laughing: @cryptowanderer @Vivek Singh @Sachin Mittal what you pulled off here was unique and special. The gratitude cup overfloweth! Onward and upward with Apollo and beyond..:bouncingparrot:

Thanks @Adam Fuller for sharing your xDai experience in todays Junto, and also @Paul Gadi for setting up.

Super useful stuff - together we shall overcome the yam inflated gas  :muscle:

Awesome event last night (for me: alternatively, yesterday, this morning)! I wanted to especially thank @Paul Gadi for the links after his presentation. I've been interested in the economics of games for a while now, and hadn't realized that there were awesome resources like <http://decontructoroffun.com|decontructoroffun.com> out there. I'm also slowly making my way through the other resources you highlighted. Thanks!

attributes.value: The Player's Paladin

Dearest Paul. What words can ever convey our thanks fully? You are a treasure and we could not have imagined anyone better to build the Gaming Track. Here is to many more collaborations to come. We love you very much, dear brother.

received.message: There are far too many people to thank but here goes. Thanks for letting me cry in Twitter Spaces today @Vivek Singh @alisha @Angela Gilhotra @cryptowanderer @Sachin Mittal. In KB4, I've bonded, spent time with or been in the presence with these amazingly inspirational womxn of color @Vienna Looi @Songyi Lee @Holly Grimm @Jasmine Wang @Michelle Ma @Denise Schaefer @Rebecca Mqamelo @Juanna Zhai. I've been so moved by the work of @Richard Blythman @Matthew Scott Jones that I hope for the future of the “metaverse” and AI, places where I have felt trapped in centralized recreating inequalities for so long, that it's such a fresh breathe of air to see these amazing founders for their work and I can't wait to see more from them and work with them somehow in some fashion at the intersection as its relevant with my work in the future. I have an extremely long list of all the folks who demo’ed today at Showcase and Expo that I either plan on somehow integrating into in my future work (be a user, beta tester, adviser on their platform). Thank you (Salamat) again to @Alex Yao Lisa Lee Lucas (co-founder of NOVA with @Nicolas Nicolas Ponette) and Michelle Tsing (laptopradio and blockchain adviser to some companies out of Kernel and Blockchain at Berkeley accelerator) for pushing me to apply. I almost didn't and I am so glad I did. It is really encouraging me to do all the things I want to with DAOs, to not compromise my values, and stay true to myself, in a world obsessed with performative isms that is the Hollywood/Silicon Valley/DC/NY power and wealth hungry addicted and controlling egos that I try so hard to resist. Today I quit 3 social media networks, dropped 3 projects that no longer made sense, and am deciding to double down on what I believe is authentic to my nature and being, that will continue to serve me well personally and professionally in my work. Thank you so much for helping me verbally process, grow, raise hard and contentious questions and receive so many more resources and feedback I am still processing I feel like I did 5 MOOCs and a degrrr in Kernel it was far more than I expected than a YC, graduate degree, or self-help coaching session. This has been powerful for me as a community organizer, entrepreneur, software engineer, computational designer, as a woman of color, colonized person, and avid reader. I so appreciate all the hard work it takes to create content, organize logistics, moderate, facilitate, and maintain as a steward and also much love to every single person in the Kernel community who has been responsive with every chat, every request, and every ask I have made whether verbal, written or otherwise. I am constantly amazed by this community and am so privileged to be a part of it. It's been an honor to be selected as a fellow and I can only hope I live up to what I set out to do next now with a framework that helps heal me and keep me grounded away from a hamster wheel that is life. I am taking a major cooling period after December and hope to share more work come 2022 with Kernel (maybe a future showcase), of all that's been incubating and cooking up in my head, behind Code editors and things I haven't pushed to GitHub, announced or made live yet. Lastly, thank you @Kevin Owocki for founding GitCoin, seeing you speak at Dystopia Labs and other conferences over the years always impressed me and I'm floored to have participated somehow in some small way related remotely to the work that you do, it is so important for the liberation of all people in the world and I hope that it continues to evolve with each Kernel block in the future.

I thought I'd drop a line here as I'm just jumping back into Kernel after quite a time away.  My web3 journey didn't start with Kernel but it did start with Gitcoin back in early 2019 after I heard a podcast with @Kevin Owocki that was my first step down the rabbit hole.  After hacking away on bounties for more than year (quite a few for Gitcoin Core), I saw the first mentions of the Kernel program and applied.  After a fruitful interview with @Vivek Singh and @Sachin Mittal, I waited a few weeks and wondered if I'd ever hear back.  I feel like the poster child for imposter syndrome in the web3 world and I was more than surprised when I got the email inviting me to join the Kernel Genesis Block.  The rest, as they say, is history.  I'm thankful for having been included in this community of builders and thinkers and also for the whole Gitcoin community of growing open source .  I'm definitely not the deepest thinker here or the best coder (not by a country mile), but it was this community that really helped me find my footing to go from where I was (someone who felt purposeless and unfruitful in my then vocation) to where I am now (an active, engaged dev working on Ethereum infrastructure who wakes up every day excited to do what I've been called to do and to see the world get turned upside down by what we're building).  So thank you @Kevin Owocki for building Gitcoin, @Vivek Singh, @Sachin Mittal,  and@cryptowanderer for Kernel, and to others along the way who have given me opportunities to build cool stuff and to be a part of web3 like @Rob Secord and @Ben Lakoff from Charged Particles, @Mike Elias from Idea Market, various folks from the Status/Nimbus team, @Shresth Agrawal, @Jose Aguinaga...etc.

Thank you @Vivek Singh  for inviting me to kernel on that ocean presentation day. And thank you for constantly uplifting me exactly when I need it the most. Thank you for writing to Alex

Thank you @Sachin Mittal for your convos with me and for your support and trust

Thank you @cryptowanderer for being the most special and unique soul I’ve ever met :heart:

Thank you @Alex Masmej  for being so extraordinary and finding the time to meet. I want more ;)))

Thank you @Octavian Todirut for the sick Kernel swag design

Thank you @Kevin Owocki  for GitCoin. I’d be stuck in miserable finance world without you

Thank you @Simona Pop for helping me with the designs organisation

Thank you @Veronica Coutts for your help with my bonding curve. Please DM me I’ll send you some NAZ :)

Thank you Wildcards team, and especially Jason for the tip about front running resistance

Thank you @Manank Patni  for your sweet Figma design

Thank you @wschwab for great convos and being the first one to clap to my primitives ;)

Thank you EVERYONE. I deeply love and appreciate you all. If at any point I can be of any service to you. Summon me ;) twitter: @AlgorithmicBot. Telegram: nazariyv

And most importantly, thank you The V (Vitalik Buterin, right?), without you, none of us would be here. You should be a role model for everyone. If I can be of any service to you at all, I’d be overwhelmed with joy to help. Lots of love everyone. You will all succeed and make this world much much better!

A gift of deep gratitude for friends old and new, for all that has been shared to honour our time together :pray:

<https://kernel.community/en/conversation/true-voice/>

cc @Harold Davis @Sparrow Read @Sebnem @Abe Uccello @Holly Grimm @Matthew Stephenson @Muhammad Hameed @Tagan Horton @alisha @Ellena Rapaport @Anna Alexa @Rebecca Mqamelo and the many others who will hopefully continue to grow this conversation over many, many years :heart:
@cryptowanderer I'm always up for moving things around for this kind of dialogue mane haha What say you @Sparrow Read @Magenta Ceiba @Holly Grimm@Vivek Singh@Sebnem@Bea DADA??

> Our common denominator seems we care as/for toolmakers and their/our ability to care about the "ethical" use of these tools (mind included)... Law of Peace, in an era this advanced connected, but also as <https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2020/01/yuval-hararis-warning-davos-speech-future-predications/|philosophically bankrupt>.
Exactly, this also might speak to your beautiful points on evolving from where we are & the pull towards unity. The Longhouse often describes this as connecting the two strands of DNA. Then often will twist the Two Row Wampum belt to resemble the double helix :slightly_smiling_face:
> This seems a natural evolution, a pull, an "ontological buoyancy" towards unity - for which we transcend our limitation: the mind that cannot resolve paradoxes, nor can see the whole no matter how many models it ensembles.. <https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/13ZAmQgBYKgzah4jY3WkExuNSzhGqSABUZzZVl-fYKn8/edit?usp=sharing|"strategically, profoundly, madly letting go"> . I'm still unable to formulate what this is about, what is it that "practically" we're talking about?  Just a year ago I wouldn't have been able to follow - nor would I be motivated to do so - this conversation... then the universe conspired :wink:
Fresh off meeting with Ron Eglash of Generative Justice research group & a young Mayan woman named Valentina, who is studying to be matrilineal midwife in Chiapas. The Longhouse interaction in the this context was fascinating to witness and study general feel of what is an extension of Two Row Wampum protocols for peace. "Expanding the dream" was a simple motif that emerged when discussing interdisciplinary prototyping for systems design. Despite largely disparate backgrounds & geographies, there was a common understanding of *where we are*, juxtaposed with where we are coming from & where we are planning to go. The Longhouse often saying "there's no leaf suspended in air attached to nothing." This seems to beg your question on the power of questions to induce peace. This seems to be the case, especially in spaces of consensus. This is why the Longhouse protocols for peaceful dialogue layered atop of consensus is a remarkable _*tool*_ to have access to in our times. "The enzyme that manages the connections of thee double helix." Indeed @Sebnem ---- _"This seems a natural evolution, a pull, an "ontological buoyancy" towards unity"_

“We are not here to make new legal codes; we are here to restore to shared awareness old laws based on multidimensional observation of who we really are. We are here to be in love.”
...
“However, if governance is about understanding the order of events, then scale is no issue, because order is definitive whereas agreement is opinionated.

Consensus is not about agreeing with other people and playing nice, it is a means of discovering truth together. And truth scales, because it is dimensionless. It rings the same in subatomic particles as it does in supernovae. We have just forgotten how to trust the capacity we each have to recognise truth, how to listen with love and speak from the heart, because it is a capacity that is accessed through the collective in a particular kind of dialogic space, and we no longer sit in such circles.”

Ty kindly Andy, this is a beautiful start :fire: Will comment on doc & definitely ping Bea, Sebnem n co too just in case :100: 

@Bea DADA @Sparrow Read @Sebnem @Magenta Ceiba @Holly Grimm :purple_heart:

@Sebnem this is beautiful love the Humming reference! And ingreedient too :joy: Made me think about importance of dosage distinguishing a medicine from a poison...what is the medicine dosage of greed? Are constraints for collective humming as opposed to majority wins structures our means to containing the greed dosage to a certain tiny amount per individual & group within the collective? Is this still greed in all this context? Or is it transformed into something else by both dosage & environment? What is this something else? Is it familiar in our modern world or specific to our ancient past? :man-shrugging::skin-tone-5: Stopping now haha just first thoughts.
@Sebnem <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pharmakon_(philosophy)> *Pharmakon*, in philosophy and critical theory, is a composite of three meanings: remedy, poison, and scapegoat
@Sebnem there is a whole lot of collective sense making opportunity with @Harold Davis and others over the course of these next weeks (and beyond, I think).

@Sebnem we can connect again ASAP, had good brief intro discussion to token engineering for communities focused on varying forms of decommodification --preservation of intrinsic value flows. Here is the Proof of Transfer (<https://docs.blockstack.org/understand-stacks/proof-of-transfer|PoX>) documentation mentioned @Sparrow Read also the <https://github.com/psq/flexr|amazing developer> of <https://github.com/psq/swapr|swapr> (decentralized exchange) mentioned (xtra <https://blog.blockstack.org/ama-with-jude-nelson-app-chains-clarity-smart-contracts-stacking-jude/|app chain> & <https://blog.blockstack.org/bringing-clarity-to-8-dangerous-smart-contract-vulnerabilities/|Smart contract> context). We are planning to reach out to this dev for the chapter work you mention Sebnem. Maybe there is chance to get similar questions answered at same time in the process? We are still in first launch weeks of the latest mainnet release, so hopefully he has some spare time & interest. :crossed_fingers::skin-tone-5:

received.message:
Hey all, time flew, and now with things calming down a bit, I want to express my gratitude towards those that made the past few months so special, It was a big wave for me and ethblockart, and without the help of mentors, fellows, and the kernel team, I wouldn't have been able to stay atop the surfboard!

For starters, I wanna express my gratitude towards many of the mentors, present and supportive in genuinely important ways throughout this adventure: Defi_Dad, @Thomas Klocanas, @Linda Xie, @Shawn Cheng @Ben Lakoff, @Dave Rodman, @Harsh Rajat and @Scott Moore. You folks are amazing and your help instrumental.

Other fellows, always positive, helpful and inspiring in the best way possible even while busy with their own adventures, like @Simon Fremaux, @Carl Farterson and the best-practices gang, @Holly Grimm, and the DADA team, even if we didn't interact much directly, know you've been an inspiration for many years!

And how can we not be grateful for the Kernel team, receiving us all with open arms and unparalleled patience and kindness, @Sachin Mittal, @Vivek Singh and others, one-of-a-kind human beings which I'm honoured to have met and spend time with. :pray:

Lastly, I can't write this without a special note to @cryptowanderer, embracing the project mission from the start, contributing in ways I couldn't have expected, making what the project is today a reality, you're amazing, thank you again.

One can say riding a market like we're experiencing today as a solo builder with a somewhat market-fit product can feel like choosing Jaws, Maui as a go-to surf spot while still learning to surf, sure some can pull off the once-in-a-lifetime herculean task of achieving so alone...But what enables surfers to, time and time again, execute this impressive feat, a humbling celebration of our ability to face head-first the scariest challenges posed by nature, are exactly other humans, community, supporters often not celebrated, from the tow-in jet sky riders, the lifeguards bringing you oxygen, to the chanting crowd by the coast and even the sharks keeping you alert.

Back to the point, what is being done here at Kernel is unique, every step planned with a level of care hard to find elsewhere, and it is also upon us all to keep this flame awake and the kernel culture principled, I hope to in the future be able to help others the same way I was helped here, for that is what makes the world go round.

For now, thank you Kernel, for all, and happy spring! :seedling:

Thanks to the Kernel Team, Mentors and awesome fellows. All of you have helped us shape some of the major decisions about our project and the way to take it forward :rocket:. I am grateful to all of you and see the relationships I build here to last forever. Deep gratitude and thanks to all of you, proud to have connected with (and learned from) @Vivek Singh @cryptowanderer @Sachin Mittal @Andrew Redden @Luka @Simona Pop @Thomas Klocanas @Linda Xie @Amy of BFLO @Tony Sheng @Angela Gilhotra @Denham -Wildcards/Float.Capital @Tarun Gupta @Anubhav Girdhar @Jo-Ann A. Hamilton @Hudson Jameson @Juan Benet @Doug Molina @Alex Salnikov 'Rarible @Ganesh Swami @Robin Davids @Ben @Dawid (dawg) @Deepcryptodive - Giel Detienne @Nazzareno Massari @Chris Furlong @Danny Zuckerman @ken @Kevin Owocki @Scott Moore, I do think am definitely missing some names here so will probably edit it in sometime :sweat_smile:.

Hey @Vivek Singh thanks for the mention. Upvest moved away from doing that due to investor pressure and market cap constraints on security tokenization plus the regulatory landscape in Germany.. and went full steam ahead in fintech with building a securities API as a neo-broker and basically getting BaFin licensed as a custodian (so like a bank - competing with the likes of solarisbank but slowly becoming like the “robinhood” for securities APIs in Germany).. [they were non-custodial before] They then hired a new CTO from transferwise, CPO from Raisin and old timer banking professionals.  Along with a (3rd) complete overhaul of the backend tech stack (always being an API company though)... Python to TS/JS to Golang. Rust assured i’m back at it again working for data-in-blockchain with @Ganesh Swami at Covalent. Which is friggin fantastic! :rocket: :fire: .

p.s: Talking about serendipity, Ganesh and I met at KERNEL :heart:  - <https://kernel-community.slack.com/archives/C016DKV7MTQ/p1597250250341100>

Hello KERNELERS!

Yesterday <https://kernel-community.slack.com/archives/C016JL4385C/p1597168559023300|evening>, we had a match-made-in-heaven :cloud: Junto with 2 esteemed guests speakers, @Chris Meisl (CTO) from <https://www.blocknative.com/|Blocknative> and @Ganesh Swami (CEO) from <https://www.covalenthq.com/|Covalent>.  The following two case studies / pre-reads were recommended and helped aid the lively discussion.
1. <https://blog.blocknative.com/blog/mempool-forensics|Mempool forensics> :bowl_with_spoon: 
2. <https://www.covalenthq.com/blog/covalent-defi-sdk/|Covalent SDK> :alembic: 
While Chris explored the ideas of _value in motion_  :star2:  covering mempool traffic :vertical_traffic_light: analytics and notifications :1234: with us. Ganesh balanced the remaining from where Chris left off by exploring _value at rest_ :cake: with smart-contracts & transactions analytics.

We also gained valuable insights on historically underlooked mempool data while taking into consideration the performance of the different kinds of nodes in the Ethereum :city_sunset: network including but not limited to how they skew any assumptions on transaction (type) distribution that we might make. Active nonce :1234: and gas price :fuelpump: management for stuck, pending and dropped, mempool transaction :swimmer: and block explorers :building_construction: data stores. We further explored on-chain data usage for delivering insights by restructuring it into a consumable formats while covering topics like EVM  :nerd_face: optimisations, performance considerations in DB latency vs verifiability :checkered_flag: rollups :space_invader: vs single row :table_tennis_paddle_and_ball: lookups, OLTP and OLAP databases, and DB primitives :construction_worker:. The overarching theme was on how we could bridge the legacy DB :steam_locomotive: world onto blockchain :bullettrain_front: and how the technologies we’re building could aid that vision.

Effectively this junto covered the entire spectrum of the happenings in the life of an Ethereum transaction :money_with_wings: and the value that it carries every step of the way. :roller_coaster: I  would highly recommend reaching out to the mentors for anything (even remotely) related to data on blockchain and look forward to our next Junto on one or more of the discussed specifics. @Sachin Mittal thanks a ton for organising this and to all the participants for engaging! One of the best Junto’s for me personally... :fire: :fireworks: :seedling:

I am so thankful!

There are far too many people to thank but here goes. Thanks for letting me cry in Twitter Spaces today @Vivek Singh @alisha @Angela Gilhotra @cryptowanderer @Sachin Mittal. In KB4, I've bonded, spent time with or been in the presence with these amazingly inspirational womxn of color @Vienna Looi @Songyi Lee @Holly Grimm @Jasmine Wang @Michelle Ma @Denise Schaefer @Rebecca Mqamelo @Juanna Zhai. I've been so moved by the work of @Richard Blythman @Matthew Scott Jones that I hope for the future of the “metaverse” and AI, places where I have felt trapped in centralized recreating inequalities for so long, that it's such a fresh breathe of air to see these amazing founders for their work and I can't wait to see more from them and work with them somehow in some fashion at the intersection as its relevant with my work in the future. I have an extremely long list of all the folks who demo’ed today at Showcase and Expo that I either plan on somehow integrating into in my future work (be a user, beta tester, adviser on their platform). Thank you (Salamat) again to @Alex Yao Lisa Lee Lucas (co-founder of NOVA with @Nicolas Nicolas Ponette) and Michelle Tsing (laptopradio and blockchain adviser to some companies out of Kernel and Blockchain at Berkeley accelerator) for pushing me to apply. I almost didn't and I am so glad I did. It is really encouraging me to do all the things I want to with DAOs, to not compromise my values, and stay true to myself, in a world obsessed with performative isms that is the Hollywood/Silicon Valley/DC/NY power and wealth hungry addicted and controlling egos that I try so hard to resist. Today I quit 3 social media networks, dropped 3 projects that no longer made sense, and am deciding to double down on what I believe is authentic to my nature and being, that will continue to serve me well personally and professionally in my work. Thank you so much for helping me verbally process, grow, raise hard and contentious questions and receive so many more resources and feedback I am still processing I feel like I did 5 MOOCs and a degrrr in Kernel it was far more than I expected than a YC, graduate degree, or self-help coaching session. This has been powerful for me as a community organizer, entrepreneur, software engineer, computational designer, as a woman of color, colonized person, and avid reader. I so appreciate all the hard work it takes to create content, organize logistics, moderate, facilitate, and maintain as a steward and also much love to every single person in the Kernel community who has been responsive with every chat, every request, and every ask I have made whether verbal, written or otherwise. I am constantly amazed by this community and am so privileged to be a part of it. It's been an honor to be selected as a fellow and I can only hope I live up to what I set out to do next now with a framework that helps heal me and keep me grounded away from a hamster wheel that is life. I am taking a major cooling period after December and hope to share more work come 2022 with Kernel (maybe a future showcase), of all that's been incubating and cooking up in my head, behind Code editors and things I haven't pushed to GitHub, announced or made live yet. Lastly, thank you @Kevin Owocki for founding GitCoin, seeing you speak at Dystopia Labs and other conferences over the years always impressed me and I'm floored to have participated somehow in some small way related remotely to the work that you do, it is so important for the liberation of all people in the world and I hope that it continues to evolve with each Kernel block in the future.

Is thirsty for the light
To get some gleams of knowledge

To memories we dream.

Save us from what our own hands might do;
lift the veil, but do not tear it.
Save us from the ego; its knife has reached our bones.

Let us turn from ourselves to You
Who are nearer to us than ourselves.

How else has a rose garden grown from these ashes?

Rumi, Mathnawi, II 2444-9

received.message: <http://www.phys.unm.edu/~tw/fas/yits/archive/oliver_thejourney.html> @Kris Is

This is a message of gratitude to @Kris Is, who showed up at CICOLAB yesterday and gave us some great advice to check out Dandelion Mané and Source Cred. This actually was not necessarily an obvious link, because Source Cred has been coming at their solution from "reputation," and we have been talking about "matching." (See here for a history of this idea: <https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lYxOK30=/>). If you watch this <https://youtu.be/Ee99RK5_Jtg|condensed video (6 min)> of last night's discussion, you can see an example of what we call "discoverability," which is huge problem within Kernel. This is because it is a highly innovative space, with high diversity of people from different backgrounds. That means that people might be working on different projects which might actually align in some way, but that is difficult to see on the surface (in other words, they would not be able to find each other using Google because of non-obvious search terms and lack of common language between different fields, or by simply listing what their project is about).  It takes a deeper dive into figuring out the "why" of what people are trying to do with their projects. So, thanks, Kris, for taking that time and making a really great connection which saved me so much work. You are a lifesaver.

In last night's session, we talked about Appreciation Bytes, our super-simple tool for noticing the often-invisible contributions of others which add to group intelligence. Our hypothesis is that we could use this to facilitate matching between a mess of groups, people, and projects, especially in a community-wide funding effort. It turns out that we have been working on the front end to what Source Cred has been developing the back end, and there is probably a high incidence of that in Kernel. Developing the machine and human technology to be able to put the memetic puzzles pieces together is a fascinating mission and one we look forward to helping to solve during our time at Kernel. @Sachin Mittal @Vivek Singh @Charles Blass

This is an amazing suggestion @Kris Is @Lauren Nignon.

Hey all, time flew, and now with things calming down a bit, I want to express my gratitude towards those that made the past few months so special, It was a big wave for me and ethblockart, and without the help of mentors, fellows, and the kernel team, I wouldn't have been able to stay atop the surfboard!

For starters, I wanna express my gratitude towards many of the mentors, present and supportive in genuinely important ways throughout this adventure: Defi_Dad, @Thomas Klocanas, @Linda Xie, @Shawn Cheng @Ben Lakoff, @Dave Rodman, @Harsh Rajat and @Scott Moore. You folks are amazing and your help instrumental.

Other fellows, always positive, helpful and inspiring in the best way possible even while busy with their own adventures, like @Simon Fremaux, @Carl Farterson and the best-practices gang, @Holly Grimm, and the DADA team, even if we didn't interact much directly, know you've been an inspiration for many years!

And how can we not be grateful for the Kernel team, receiving us all with open arms and unparalleled patience and kindness, @Sachin Mittal, @Vivek Singh and others, one-of-a-kind human beings which I'm honoured to have met and spend time with. :pray:

Lastly, I can't write this without a special note to @cryptowanderer, embracing the project mission from the start, contributing in ways I couldn't have expected, making what the project is today a reality, you're amazing, thank you again.

One can say riding a market like we're experiencing today as a solo builder with a somewhat market-fit product can feel like choosing Jaws, Maui as a go-to surf spot while still learning to surf, sure some can pull off the once-in-a-lifetime herculean task of achieving so alone...But what enables surfers to, time and time again, execute this impressive feat, a humbling celebration of our ability to face head-first the scariest challenges posed by nature, are exactly other humans, community, supporters often not celebrated, from the tow-in jet sky riders, the lifeguards bringing you oxygen, to the chanting crowd by the coast and even the sharks keeping you alert.

Back to the point, what is being done here at Kernel is unique, every step planned with a level of care hard to find elsewhere, and it is also upon us all to keep this flame awake and the kernel culture principled, I hope to in the future be able to help others the same way I was helped here, for that is what makes the world go round.

For now, thank you Kernel, for all, and happy spring! :seedling:

received.message: There are far too many people to thank but here goes. Thanks for letting me cry in Twitter Spaces today @Vivek Singh @alisha @Angela Gilhotra @cryptowanderer @Sachin Mittal. In KB4, I've bonded, spent time with or been in the presence with these amazingly inspirational womxn of color @Vienna Looi @Songyi Lee @Holly Grimm @Jasmine Wang @Michelle Ma @Denise Schaefer @Rebecca Mqamelo @Juanna Zhai. I've been so moved by the work of @Richard Blythman @Matthew Scott Jones that I hope for the future of the “metaverse” and AI, places where I have felt trapped in centralized recreating inequalities for so long, that it's such a fresh breathe of air to see these amazing founders for their work and I can't wait to see more from them and work with them somehow in some fashion at the intersection as its relevant with my work in the future. I have an extremely long list of all the folks who demo’ed today at Showcase and Expo that I either plan on somehow integrating into in my future work (be a user, beta tester, adviser on their platform). Thank you (Salamat) again to @Alex Yao Lisa Lee Lucas (co-founder of NOVA with @Nicolas Nicolas Ponette) and Michelle Tsing (laptopradio and blockchain adviser to some companies out of Kernel and Blockchain at Berkeley accelerator) for pushing me to apply. I almost didn't and I am so glad I did. It is really encouraging me to do all the things I want to with DAOs, to not compromise my values, and stay true to myself, in a world obsessed with performative isms that is the Hollywood/Silicon Valley/DC/NY power and wealth hungry addicted and controlling egos that I try so hard to resist. Today I quit 3 social media networks, dropped 3 projects that no longer made sense, and am deciding to double down on what I believe is authentic to my nature and being, that will continue to serve me well personally and professionally in my work. Thank you so much for helping me verbally process, grow, raise hard and contentious questions and receive so many more resources and feedback I am still processing I feel like I did 5 MOOCs and a degrrr in Kernel it was far more than I expected than a YC, graduate degree, or self-help coaching session. This has been powerful for me as a community organizer, entrepreneur, software engineer, computational designer, as a woman of color, colonized person, and avid reader. I so appreciate all the hard work it takes to create content, organize logistics, moderate, facilitate, and maintain as a steward and also much love to every single person in the Kernel community who has been responsive with every chat, every request, and every ask I have made whether verbal, written or otherwise. I am constantly amazed by this community and am so privileged to be a part of it. It's been an honor to be selected as a fellow and I can only hope I live up to what I set out to do next now with a framework that helps heal me and keep me grounded away from a hamster wheel that is life. I am taking a major cooling period after December and hope to share more work come 2022 with Kernel (maybe a future showcase), of all that's been incubating and cooking up in my head, behind Code editors and things I haven't pushed to GitHub, announced or made live yet. Lastly, thank you @Kevin Owocki for founding GitCoin, seeing you speak at Dystopia Labs and other conferences over the years always impressed me and I'm floored to have participated somehow in some small way related remotely to the work that you do, it is so important for the liberation of all people in the world and I hope that it continues to evolve with each Kernel block in the future.

Thank you <!subteam^S01JV5JPV6E|@kernel-stewards> and all the people I met along the way for this amazing journey.

:sunny: I started KERNEL very hopeful, thinking I had found likeminded people, a community to learn, to build, and to be myself and not have to explain context before saying something.

:partly_sunny_rain: Then I realized how wrong I was! I would be asking myself "WTF are they talking about?" during fireside chats or random juntos; I'd get frustrated with how (maybe intentionally) unclear KERNEL is (you have to create your own adventure, of which KERNEL is a tool... I guess); I'd get a little jealous seeing all the people saying thank you on this channel, feeling "should I be doing more to get as enthusiastic and happy as them?"; and just generally anxious for not having enough time to be with my family, do my full-time job (not for long), work on the next adventure, and also read and watch all the curated material.

I'm not gonna lie, I still have those negative (complementary opposing) feelings... at least sometimes :slightly_smiling_face:.

:mostly_sunny:But then I realized people and groups don't (necessarily) care about my expectations. I really understood and appreciated the "group with loosely shared interests" description of the fellows. I started to find new language to express my ideas, to communicate better, and to just appreciate those conflicting feelings, because they moved me to action. I found myself having more conversations and asking better questions (initially just to myself). And finally, thanks to a conversation with @Sarah Hamburg, who wisely said "KERNEL is a marathon, not a sprint" (Thanks for that, Sarah!), I started to think more long-term.

:kernel-love: Thank you for igniting this in me. From this inner turmoil, love-hate relationship, that KERNEL has been, a new (hopefully better) Guillermo emerges.
I look forward to more adventures together and continue to obsessively check this slack in the future (I struggle to control my FOMO). Thanks @Sarah Hamburg @Holly Grimm @Saskia Westhof @Aimara Garcia Cabezas @Greg Becker @Ray Di Felice @snax y-not @Tim Courtney for amazing conversations.

Finally, the whole theme of KERNEL reminded me of <https://sites.evergreen.edu/politicalshakespeares/wp-content/uploads/sites/226/2015/12/Borges-Tl%C3%B6n-Uqbar-Orbius-Tertius.pdf|"Tlon, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius">, by my favorite author Jorge Luis Borges. Check it out.
> "Then English and French and mere Spanish will disappear from the globe. The world will be Tlon."
Thank you for organizing such a great convo junto today @Vienna Looi. Loved learning with you and @Holly Grimm. You all have such beautiful minds

We had an absolutely fantastic "Climate Impact Group" kickoff chat on Monday! The intention was just get together, geek out on all things decarbonising web 3 & leveraging things like DeFi to accelerate the vision of a planet positive, carbon negative future for all including jamming on things like the devastation faced by our oceans in example.

If you missed it, don't worry, you can find the recording in <#C01UUEDM934|feed-session-recordings> but essentially we spent a lot of time on intros & getting to know each other better which was lovely, had some climate convo led by @Raphael Haupt & some others, deciding that essentially we would co-ord in <#C01KHR1M0LA|jam-climate> & find a time that suited all of us as best as possible to make the event a reoccurring thing.

Consensus is not about agreeing with other people and playing nice, it is a means of discovering truth together. And truth scales, because it is dimensionless. It rings the same in subatomic particles as it does in supernovae. We have just forgotten how to trust the capacity we each have to recognise truth, how to listen with love and speak from the heart, because it is a capacity that is accessed through the collective in a particular kind of dialogic space, and we no longer sit in such circles.”

received.message:
This is a message of gratitude to @Kris Is, who showed up at CICOLAB yesterday and gave us some great advice to check out Dandelion Mané and Source Cred. This actually was not necessarily an obvious link, because Source Cred has been coming at their solution from "reputation," and we have been talking about "matching." (See here for a history of this idea: <https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lYxOK30=/>). If you watch this <https://youtu.be/Ee99RK5_Jtg|condensed video (6 min)> of last night's discussion, you can see an example of what we call "discoverability," which is huge problem within Kernel. This is because it is a highly innovative space, with high diversity of people from different backgrounds. That means that people might be working on different projects which might actually align in some way, but that is difficult to see on the surface (in other words, they would not be able to find each other using Google because of non-obvious search terms and lack of common language between different fields, or by simply listing what their project is about).  It takes a deeper dive into figuring out the "why" of what people are trying to do with their projects. So, thanks, Kris, for taking that time and making a really great connection which saved me so much work. You are a lifesaver.

In last night's session, we talked about Appreciation Bytes, our super-simple tool for noticing the often-invisible contributions of others which add to group intelligence. Our hypothesis is that we could use this to facilitate matching between a mess of groups, people, and projects, especially in a community-wide funding effort. It turns out that we have been working on the front end to what Source Cred has been developing the back end, and there is probably a high incidence of that in Kernel. Developing the machine and human technology to be able to put the memetic puzzles pieces together is a fascinating mission and one we look forward to helping to solve during our time at Kernel. @Sachin Mittal @Vivek Singh @Charles Blass

“Know that thankfulness is from the highest of stations, and it is higher than patience and fear and detachment of this world.”  - Imam Al-Ghazali

Cultivating gratitude is the most beautiful art we can create. The social, emotional dynamics and constant personal growth that is required for the deep collaboration that forges hyper effective teams is grossly understated. For that reason I am grateful to my friend, peer, co-founder and comrade in Web 3 @Tagan Horton. Without her spirit, energy, fortitude and self determination the KERNEL experience and Dakar Gallery would not be possible. 

KERNEL has been a lesson in play and a journey of gratitude. While it is impossible to pinpoint one person or Kernel experience I am grateful to @Vivek Singh for setting the tone for gratitude per our first conversation days before KERNEL started. received.message: Thank you @Dave Rodman for the legal advisement yesterday during Office Hours. Always important to hear attorneys’ objective opinion to make the most informed decision as a founder.

Hey all, time flew, and now with things calming down a bit, I want to express my gratitude towards those that made the past few months so special, It was a big wave for me and ethblockart, and without the help of mentors, fellows, and the kernel team, I wouldn't have been able to stay atop the surfboard!

For starters, I wanna express my gratitude towards many of the mentors, present and supportive in genuinely important ways throughout this adventure: Defi_Dad, @Thomas Klocanas, @Linda Xie, @Shawn Cheng @Ben Lakoff, @Dave Rodman, @Harsh Rajat and @Scott Moore. You folks are amazing and your help instrumental.

Other fellows, always positive, helpful and inspiring in the best way possible even while busy with their own adventures, like @Simon Fremaux, @Carl Farterson and the best-practices gang, @Holly Grimm, and the DADA team, even if we didn't interact much directly, know you've been an inspiration for many years!

And how can we not be grateful for the Kernel team, receiving us all with open arms and unparalleled patience and kindness, @Sachin Mittal, @Vivek Singh and others, one-of-a-kind human beings which I'm honoured to have met and spend time with. :pray:

Lastly, I can't write this without a special note to @cryptowanderer, embracing the project mission from the start, contributing in ways I couldn't have expected, making what the project is today a reality, you're amazing, thank you again.

One can say riding a market like we're experiencing today as a solo builder with a somewhat market-fit product can feel like choosing Jaws, Maui as a go-to surf spot while still learning to surf, sure some can pull off the once-in-a-lifetime herculean task of achieving so alone...But what enables surfers to, time and time again, execute this impressive feat, a humbling celebration of our ability to face head-first the scariest challenges posed by nature, are exactly other humans, community, supporters often not celebrated, from the tow-in jet sky riders, the lifeguards bringing you oxygen, to the chanting crowd by the coast and even the sharks keeping you alert.

Back to the point, what is being done here at Kernel is unique, every step planned with a level of care hard to find elsewhere, and it is also upon us all to keep this flame awake and the kernel culture principled, I hope to in the future be able to help others the same way I was helped here, for that is what makes the world go round.

For now, thank you Kernel, for all, and happy spring! :seedling:
